stem: A 76-year-old client with end-stage heart failure has a signed 'Do Not Resuscitate' (DNR) order in their chart. They have now gone into cardiac arrest. Their son is at the bedside yelling, 'Save them! Do everything!' Based on the documentation in the Ethics Committee Review & Advance Directives tab, complete the bowtie by selecting the most likely legal standing, the two actions the nurse should take, and the two parameters the nurse should monitor.

tabs.title: SBAR
tabs.content:
Situation: Cardiac arrest with conflicting directives.
Background: Admitted for palliative care. DNR signed and witnessed on admission.
Assessment: Client is pulseless and apneic. Son is emotionally distraught.
Recommendation: Adherence to the legal standard of care.

tabs.title: Advance Directives Log
tabs.content:
DocumentStatusNotes
DNR OrderSigned / ActiveVerified by primary MD
Living WillActiveStates 'No chest compressions'

tabs.title: Vital Signs
tabs.content: BP 0/0, HR 0 (Asystole), RR 0. SpO2 not detectable.

actionOptions.text: Provide emotional support and a private space for the grieving family
Begin chest compressions immediately to avoid a lawsuit from the son
Intubate the client but do not provide chemical resuscitation

parameterOptions.text: Presence of a signed, witnessed DNR order in the chart
Family's understanding of the client's end-of-life wishes
Daily measurement of fasting serum glucose
Presence of a positive Trousseau sign

rationale.correct: This is a case of a Legally Enforceable DNR Status (c1). If a competent patient signs a DNR, a family member (even a Medical Power of Attorney) cannot overrule it once the patient is in arrest. Resuscitation would be a violation of the patient's autonomy and battery. The nurse must hold all efforts (a1) and focus on family support/grief management (a2). Key parameters include verifying the chart document (p1) and assessing the family's understanding/grief needs (p2).
clinicalPearls: A DNR is a medical order; a Living Will is a legal wish. You need the order in the chart to act.
The Medical POA (Decider)'s job is to fulfill the patient's known wishes, not their own.
If in doubt during a code with no paperwork, you MUST resuscitate; but if the DNR is in hand, you MUST STOP.

questionTrap.trap: Resuscitating because the son is yelling 'Save them!'.
questionTrap.howToOvercome: Resuscitation against a known DNR is an ethical and legal violation. The nurse must be the 'Voice for the Patient,' even after they have died.

mnemonic.title: DNR Check
mnemonic.expansion: D-Document present. N-No compressions. R-Respect patient's choice.
